title: Intermediate - At The Airport
description: Learn at the airport through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Next please! Hello sir, may I see your passport please?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, here you go.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Will you be checking any bags.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, I'd like to check three pieces.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, sir. Airline policy allows only two pieces of checked luggage, at twenty kilograms each, plus one piece of carry-on luggage. I will have to charge you extra for the additional suitcase.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What? Why! I am taking an intercontinental flight! I'm flying sixteen thousand kms! How am I supposed to only take two, twenty kilo bags? That's absurd!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I am sorry, sir, there's nothing I can do. You cannot board the flight with that large bag either. Carry-on bags must fit in the over-head compartment or under your seat. That bag is clearly too big.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Now I see. You charge next to nothing for an international ticket, but when it comes to charging for any other small thing, you charge an arm and a leg! So tell me, miss, how much will I have to pay for all of this.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Let's see... six hundred and twenty-five US dollars.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: That's more than my round-trip ticket!

vocabulary.definition: Very cheap, inexpensive
Get on the plane
Between continents
The bags that one can carry onto the plane
Piece of luggage; one bag
Register bags with the airline and give them to be put on the plane
A document showing the identity of someone when outside his country
Phrase used to indicate that something is very expensive
A device that senses the presence of metal
A pass that authorizes a passenger to get on an airplane
An instrument or machine for weighing
A short stop or break in a journey, usually imposed by scheduling requirements
A trip from one place to another and back, usually over the same route

title: Elementary - Star Trek The Lost Generation
description: Learn star trek the lost generation through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Captain, we're under attack by an unidentified ship.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Damage report.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: We've sustained heavy damage to the engines. We've lost our warp drive.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: We'll have to attempt to make contact. This is Captain Picard of the Starship Enterprise. We don't wish to engage. What is the nature of this attack?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: No! You're not doing it right! Kor doesn't sound like that. His voice is deeper!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: No! If you can't do a Klingon voice, I'll have to find a more serious Star Trek fan actor who actually can, OK?

vocabulary.definition: Being attacked
Not known,having no identity
To experience or suffer
The engine system used by a spacecraft to travel faster than the speed of light
To start fighting
Basic reason
An organized group of people sent to look for someone or somthing that is missing or lost
Low in pitch; resonant
Artificial hair
A ficticious, futuristic weapon that can stun or kill an enemy
The central point of the ship where the captain comands and orders are taken
A virtual reality simulation room where places and scenarios can be loaded
The action of transporting a person immediately from one place to another in less than a second
A member of the crew with the lowest rank

title: Elementary - At The Pharmacy
description: Learn at the pharmacy through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hello sir, how can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, I need this prescription please.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Let's see. Okay, so 50 mg of Prozac, would you prefer this in capsule or tablet?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Capsules are fine.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, you should take 1 capsule 3 times a day. Be sure not to take it on an empty stomach, and also, don't ever mix it with alcohol!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, I know. It's not the first time I'm taking this! Don't worry, I won't overdose!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, anything else I can get you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh, yes, I almost forgot! Can I also get some eye drops and um, some condoms?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sure. Darn condoms aren't registered in our system.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh, well that's okay, I'll get some later, thanks... Really it's no problem.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Just hang on there a sec. Can I get a price check on " Fun Times Ribbed Condoms" please!

vocabulary.definition: A list of drugs written by doctor
A unit for measuring weight
(drug) contained in a plastic container
(drug) formed in round hard shape
Take more drugs than suggested
Liquid used to drop into eyes to treat eye diseases
Hold on
Type in the number of something to check it's price
A device made of a hollow tube and a needle that is used to force fluids into or take fluids out of the body
A usually sweet liquid that contains medicine used to stop coughing —called also cough medicine
A covering (such as a strip of cloth) that protects or supports part of the body that has been hurt
A liquid that is used to make things lighter in color or to kill bacteria
A smooth substance that is rubbed on the skin to help heal a wound or to reduce pain or discomfort

title: Elementary - Getting A Hair Cut
description: Learn getting a hair cut through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hello there! Come on in! Don't just stand there! Come and take a seat!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Um, okay. Well, I just want a trim. Nothing too fancy.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Oh my gosh! Your hair is amazing! So silky, so shiny! I am going to work my magic on your hair! You hear me? You are going to look like a million bucks!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Okay. Um... can you make sure my sideburns are even and you just take a little off the top.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Don't you worry, I'll take care of everything! ( starts cutting) Oh my god! I just love your curly hair! It's so fluffy and cute! You should totally let it grow out. An afro would look great on you!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Um... no.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, but you are going to be my masterpiece!

vocabulary.definition: Do something. An action is required
Choose a place to sit
A short cut of hair to make one look clean
Very fashionable
Resembling silk, very smooth
Having a smooth and bright appearance
Very good. To look great
Hair that grows on the sides of man
Hair in form of round shape
Soft
Grow long
A kind of hairstyle which very curly hair is formed into round ball
A type of hairstyle where the hair is cut very short with an electric razor
A hairstyle which consists of shaving both sides of the head, leaving a strip of noticeably longer hair on top
A type of hairstyle where the hair on top is left a bit long and styled upwards, resulting in square looking haircut
In which most or all of the hair on the head is pulled away from the face, gathered and secured at the back of the head with a hair tie or clip and allowed to hang freely from that point
Formed by intertwining three or more strands of hair so that the result is similar to a woven textile.

title: Elementary - Happy Hour
description: Learn happy hour through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hey man, what do you have on tap?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Heineken and Budweiser. We have a two-for-one happy hour special.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Cool, gimme a pint of Heineken and half a pint of Bud.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Okay...A pint of Heineken and and half a pint of bud for table six! And what about some appetizers?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sure! Let's have some nachos and mozzarella sticks.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Okay. That'll be 80 bucks.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Wait... What!

vocabulary.definition: Dollar (informal)
Fried Italian cheese
A dish with tortilla chips and melted cheese cooked together
A small dish served before meal
A measuring unit which is equal to 0.473 litres
A sale; a special price
A period of time at a bar when drinks are sold cheaper than usual
Buy one and take one free
Beer served from a barrel; not in a bottle or can
A menu or list of drinks served in a restaurant or bar
A relaxed, casual bar where beer is served
Alcoholic drink made from one or more liqueur and other ingredients
Strong alcohol drink such as gin, rum, vodka, etc

title: Elementary - How Would You Like Your Eggs
description: Learn how would you like your eggs through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Wow, you're up early today! What's for breakfast?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I felt like baking, so I made some muffins.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Smells good! I'll make some coffee. Do you want me to make you some eggs?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure, I’ll take mine, sunny side up.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Eww, I don't know how you can eat your eggs like that! Ever since I was small, I've had eggs and soldiers.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You know, my dad had scrambled eggs eggs every morning for twenty years. It drove my mom crazy!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: You know what really drives me crazy? When I ask for soft boiled eggs, and they overcook them, so they come out hard boiled! How can you dip your toast into a hard boiled egg?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You're so picky sometimes.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Here you go, honey, fried eggs.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Dammit! I asked for sunny side up! How many times do I have to tell you.

vocabulary.definition: Cook in the oven
A small break or cake people usually eat for breakfast
With egg fried on only one side
Soft-boiled eggs with strips of buttered toast on it which people usually eat for breakfast
A way of cooking eggs by mixing them in a pan
Eggs cooked in the shell so the yellow part is still soft and wet
Egg cooked in the shell until the inside becomes solid
Too careful at selecting things and usually hard to please
The egg of a bird (especially a chicken or a duck) people usually eat as food
Female chicken
An egg friend on both sides; cooked so the yolk is still soft
Eggs mixed, then cooked, and then folded in half;
The yellow part of the egg
The white part of the egg
A large, flat pot used for cooking eggs and other things

title: Elementary - Calling The Office
description: Learn calling the office through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ello-hay, Aniel-day eaking-spay, ow-hay ay-may I elp-hay ou-yay

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ay-hay, Aniel-day, Ulie-jay ere-hay

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ay-hay, Ulie-jay, ow-hay are ou-yay?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Actually, I’m eeling-fay ite-quay ill otday-tay.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I’m orry-say oo-tay ear-hay, at-they. ut-way is ong-wray?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I ink-thay I’m oming-cay own-day ith-way uh-they oo-flay. I ave-hay a eadache-hay, a ore-say oat-thray and I’m eeling-fay ighly-slay everish-fay.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I ee-say. O-say ou’re-yay alling-cay in ick-say?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Es-yay, I uz-way oping-hay oo-tay ake-tay uh-they ay-day off oo-tay eecover-ray.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ok, en-they. Ay-tray and et-gay ome-say est-ray.

title: Elementary - Receptionist
description: Learn receptionist through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Good afternoon. May I help you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, I'm here to see Joanna Stevens. I have an appointment at four.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Certainly, may I take your name? I'll let her know you've arrived.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure, it's Josh O'Neil.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ms. Stevens will be with you momentarily. Can I offer you something to drink?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, a coffee would be nice, thank you.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Here you are. Ms. Stevens is ready for you now. I'll show you to her office, right this way.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Just watch your step here...

vocabulary.definition: With out doubt; of course
Polite way to ask for someone's name
Tell someone
In a very short time
Is prepared to meet with you
Show a person the way to a place
Phrase you use to show someone the direction to walk
Secretary
The waiting area of a building
The desk at the  entrance of a building where the receptionist sits
Receive and direct phone calls
A system used to connect phone calls to many different phone lines within a building

title: Elementary - Swim faster
description: Learn swim faster through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: This is such a beautiful day! Great for sailing!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: It sure is! The water looks so nice! Anchor the boat for a little while. I'm going to take a dip.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Why are you doggy-paddling? I taught you how to swim! Do your breast stroke!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I get too tired! I'll just backstroke, it's easier!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Try kicking your legs more. That's good. Don't go out too far!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: It's Jump in!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Kathy! Get back here! I see a shark!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ahhhh!!!! Help me! Help! Bring the boat closer! The shark is coming straight towards me!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: It's right under you! Kathy!!!!!

vocabulary.definition: Travel in a boat that is powered by wind
For a short amount of time
A swim
Swim like a dog
Way of swimming where the person moves the arms and legs in a half-circle in front of them; like a frog
Swim on your back with arms moving up and down in a circle
Directly in the direction of something
Clothes you wear when you go swimming (AmE)
Clothes you wear when you go swimming (BrE)
Piece of soft cloth you use to dry yourself after swimming or bathing
Lie in the sun and try to make your skin more brown
Jump into the water with your head first

title: Elementary - Pizza Delivery
description: Learn pizza delivery through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Good evening, Pizza House. This is Marty speaking. May I take your order?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Um yes… I’d like a medium pizza with pepperoni, olives, and extra cheese.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: We have a two-for-one special on large pizzas. Would you like a large pizza instead?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure, that sounds good.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Great! Would you like your second pizza to be the same as the first?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: No, make the second one with ham, pineapple and green peppers. Oh, and make it thin crust.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, thin crust. Your total is $21.50 and your order will arrive in thirty minutes or it's free!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Perfect. Thank you. Bye..

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sir, wait!! I need your address!

vocabulary.definition: An average size, not too big or small
Complete amount you must pay
In replacement of
Seems or appears to be okay, I agree
A spicy sausage usually on pizza
A small, egg-shaped black or green fruit that is used as food or for making oil
The border of a pizza, or bread
Pay for one and get another one free
Sum of everything
Food that is quickly made and convenient if you are in a hurry
Transported or taken to your house
A mix of flour and water that is used to make the base of a pizza
Food you take away from the restaurant to eat (AmE)

title: Elementary - What a Bargain
description: Learn what a bargain through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hello. May I help you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, this dress is really nice! How much is it?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That one is one hundred and fifty dollars.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: One hundred and fifty dollars? What about this other one over here?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That's one hundred and forty dollars.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hmm...that's a bit out of my price range. Can you give me a better deal?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: This is an exclusive design by DaMarco! It's a bargain at that price.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I don't know. I think I'll shop around.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, okay, how about one hundred dollars?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: That's still more than I wanted to spend. What if I take both dresses?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, I can give you a special discount, just because you seem like a nice person. One hundred and ninety dollars for both.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I don't know... It's still a bit pricey.... Thanks anyway.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, my final price! One hundred dollars for both! That's two for the price of one. That's my last offer!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Great! You've got a deal!

vocabulary.definition: A good deal, a cheap price
Look in many stores and try to find the best price
A lowering of the price of something
Not common, unique
Too expensive, can't afford it
An opportunity to buy something at a low price
Expensive
Agreement to buy something
A special discount or offer on goods and services
Money in the form of coins and bills
Card that is used to buy things and pay at a later time
To discuss and fight for a better price
A free item that is usually given to promote a product

title: Elementary - Small Talk
description: Learn small talk through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Morning.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hi there, Mr. Anderson! How are you on this fine morning?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Fine, thank you.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: It sure is cold this morning, isn't it? I barely even got out of bed!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Yeah. It’s pretty cold, alright.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Did you catch the news this morning? I heard that there was a fire on Byron Street.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: No, I didn't hear about that.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Did you happen to watch the football game last night? The Patriots scored in the last minute!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: No, I don’t like football.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh… By the way, I saw you with your daughter at the office Christmas party. She is really beautiful!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: She’s my wife! Oh, here’s my floor! Nice talking to you. Goodbye.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sir, this is the fifty-sixth floor! We are on the seventieth!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That’s okay, I'll take the stairs!

vocabulary.definition: Affirmation or confirmation of something
Hardly, could almost not
Hear, listen to
By chance or casualty someone did something
Phrased used to interject another topic in a conversation
Go up the stairs, use the stairs
Short, firendly conversation about things that are not important
Talk (informal)
Talk with people to form business connections
Difficult to deal with
A feeling of being embarrassed or uneasy

title: Elementary - I need more time
description: Learn i need more time through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: So, Casey, how are things going with the photos for the press kit?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, I've been meaning to talk to you about that. I might need to ask for an extension on that deadline.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: You've had over a month to get this finalized! Why are things delayed?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, the thing is, we ran into a lot of problems...

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I'm not looking for excuses here. I just want to get this finished on time!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I know, and I apologize for the delay. But some things were just beyond my control. I had trouble booking the the photographer, and then Michael was sick for three weeks, so I couldn't include him in the photos, and the design team lost all the files, so I had to redo the pictures.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I'm not going to put this off any longer, Casey! I want those photos ASAP!

vocabulary.definition: Group of photos, documents, articles, and information about a company given to reporters, newspapers, magazines, etc.
Intend, plan to do something
Make a deadline longer, extra time to do something
The date when something must be finished
Finish, decide on all the details
Late
Meet or encounter
Not able to control something
Plan to do something later
The date when something must be finished or happen
Not do something now that should be done; do something later procrastinate
Late with a project or things you have to do
Delay or slow something
A deadline that is really difficult to meet

title: Elementary - Can I ask you a favor
description: Learn can i ask you a favor through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Um, sorry to bother you um... my name is Rachel. I'm new here. Can I ask you a favor?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hi Rachel, welcome on board. I'm afraid I can't help you right now. I'm getting ready for a very important meeting.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Excuse me, but can I bother you for a sec?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sorry to interrupt you Sean, could you do me a quick favor?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Geeze! I just want to know where the bathroom is! What's wrong with you people!

vocabulary.definition: Annoy or disturb someone

vocabulary.word: Can I ask you a favor (phrase)
vocabulary.definition: Ask someone to do a kind and helpful thing
To the company
Polite way of asking if you can interrupt someone
In the place of
Phrase used to begin speaking to someone when they are busy doing or saying something
Do a small, helpful thing that won't take a long time
Help me
Help me with something
Cause someone to feel slightly angry
Bother or annoy someone (informal)
Stop someone from working, or doing something

title: Elementary - My New Boyfriend
description: Learn my new boyfriend through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Irene! I heard you were on a date last night! So, how did it go? I want all the juicy details!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Um... well, actually, we had a fantastic time last night. He was...amazing!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, now you really have to fill me in. What's he like?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: He's really good looking; he's quite tall, around 6'1'', he's in his early thirties, and he's got the most beautiful dark brown eyes...

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: He sounds hot! What does he do for a living?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You know what, this is the best part. David is a junior investment banker at Fortune Bank, so he's got a great career path ahead of him!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hold on a sec, his name is David?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That's my brother!

vocabulary.definition: Get the information from someone
Exciting pieces of information
Give me more information
Handsome
Attractive
A planned, logical progression of jobs within a profession throughout working life
Have a pleasing appearance
Attractive, exciting and appealing
Very loving and gentle
Good looking

title: Elementary - Canceling an Appointment
description: Learn canceling an appointment through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hello, Samantha speaking.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hi Samantha. This is Angela calling.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Oh, hi Angela, what's up?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'm just calling about our meeting today. I wonder, is it possible to reschedule our appointment in the afternoon? I have a bit of an emergency that I need to take care of.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Let me see, it shouldn't be too much of a problem...

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'm really sorry, I hope it doesn't inconvenience you too much, it's just this thing came up, and ...

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Angela, you know what, I can't make it to our meeting, either. Why don't we postpone it to tomorrow afternoon at the same time?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sounds great. See you tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What? No wonder she told me she couldn't make it to the meeting, oh, no, I think she saw me...

vocabulary.definition: What is the matter
Schedule something for a different time
Cause problem or trouble
Occur in an unexpected way
Come
Decide to do something at a later time
Not surprisingly
Two or more appointments scheduled at the same time
Cancel
Have two appointments or meetings at the same time
Move a meeting or appointment to a later time
A promise or offer to do something in the future that is not possible to do now

title: Elementary - Foul
description: Learn foul through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Has the game started yet?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, about 5 minutes ago.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Who’s winning?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: The Bulls, of course!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: What! That wasn’t a foul! C'mon, ref!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Don't worry, Shaq always screws up free throws.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: You were right! He didn't make the shot!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: That was a great shot! A three pointer, yeah!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Did you see that? He traveled and the ref didn't call it!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: This ref needs glasses. Hey ref, open your eyes! I can't believe he didn't see that!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay... end of the first quarter... Alright, I'm gonna make a beer run.

vocabulary.definition: An act in sports that is against the rules
Person who makes sure that players act according to the rules in a game or sport (informal)
Make a mistake
A chance to shoot the ball due to a foul made by the opponent
Successfully throw a ball toward a goal (sports)
A shot that scores three points in a game
Take more steps with the basketball than the rule allows
The act of quickly going to get beer
Place where basketball is played
An action where the ball is passed that helps score a goal
Put your body between an opposing player and the ball
Jump in the air and shoot the ball while
Grab and control the ball after the other team missed a shot
Intercept a pass between two players of the opposite team

title: Elementary - Asking for time Off
description: Learn asking for time off through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Mr. McKenna, do you have a second? I need to talk to you about something.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure, Liv, what can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, I was just wondering... you see, I know I've used up all my vacation days this year, but my sister is getting married, and the wedding is overseas, and, well...

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You wanna take some time off, is that right?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, sir, I was just hoping that I might be able to take some unpaid leave this year.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What dates are you planning on taking off? I'll need at least two months notice, so that I can plan for your absence.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I was thinking of taking off from September first until the thirtieth. Would you be okay with that?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I guess so.

title: Elementary - Making an Appointment
description: Learn making an appointment through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hello, Fairbrook Consulting, how may I help you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, this is Julianne Horton, and I'm calling to arrange an appointment with Ms. McNealy.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Certainly, what day were you thinking of?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: How's Thursday? Does she have any time available then?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Um... let me double check...unfortunately, she's booked solid on Thursday, how does next Monday work for you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Actually, I've got something scheduled on Monday. Can she do Tuesday?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sure, Tuesday's perfect. May I ask where you're calling from?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure, Merton Financial Advisors.

dialogue.speaker: A

title: Elementary - I can see clearly now
description: Learn i can see clearly now through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hello, Arthur. What seems to be the problem?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hey doc. Well, I think I might need glasses. I'm getting headaches, and I really struggle to see things that are far away. But I have always had 20/20 vision.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sounds like you may be far-sighted. OK, then, cover your left eye and read the chart in front of you.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Mmm… X, E, R, 3, a question mark, and I can't quite make out the other symbol but I think it's the peace sign.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Wow, Arthur! You're as blind as a bat!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, I know, my vision is really blurry at times.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ok, then, head on over to the other room and pick out some frames while I fill out your prescription.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Thanks, doc!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Arthur, that's the bathroom.

title: Elementary - Here Comes the Bride
description: Learn here comes the bride through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I can't believe that Anthony is finally getting married!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, well, it's about time. He's been living with his parents for forty years!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Don't be mean. Look, here come the bridesmaids! Their dresses look beautiful!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Who are those kids walking down the aisle?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That's the flower girl and the ring bearer. I'm pretty sure they're the groom's niece and nephew. Oh, they look so cute!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I just hope the priest makes it quick. I'm starving. I hope the food's good at the reception.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That’s all you ever think about, food! Oh, I think the bride's coming now! She looks gorgeous. Wait, what's she doing? Where's she going?

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Right this way, sir.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Mr. Corlone, I’m really sorry to trouble you, but I need your help.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, sir, you see, this recession has hit me pretty hard; I lost my job and I’m in a lot of debt.

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.text: Oh... I can’t hear a thing! Excuse me, can you keep it down?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Someone’s phone is ringing!

title: Elementary - What is your name again
description: Learn what is your name again through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Nick! How's it going?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh, hey...

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: What are you doing in this neightbourhood? Do you live around here?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Actually, my office is right around the corner.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: It was great to meet you last week at the conference. I really enjoyed our conversation about foreign investment.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah, it was really interesting. You know, I'm in a bit of a hurry, but here's my card. We should definitely meet up again and continue our discussion.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sure, you still have my contact details, right ?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You know what, this is really embarrassing, but your name has just slipped my mind. Can you remind me?

dialogue.speaker: A

title: Elementary - Virus
description: Learn virus through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Oh great! This stupid computer froze again! That’s the third time today! Hey Samuel, can you come take a look at my PC? It’s acting up again. It must have a virus or something.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Just give me a second; I’ll be right up.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I ran a virus scan on your computer, and it turns out that you have a lot of infected files!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: But I’m quite careful when I’m browsing the internet, I have no idea how I could have picked up a virus.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, you have to make sure that your anti-virus software is updated regularly; yours wasn't up to date, that's probably what was causing your problems.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ok. Anything else?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, try not to kick or hit the computer!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Um yeah… Sorry about that.

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: ...like I told you before, we just don't have the resources to hire you an assistant.

dialogue.text: I understand that, but the fact is we're understaffed.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: The timing is just not right. The economy is bad, and it's too risky to take on new staff.

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.text: Good afternoon. What can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.text: I'm sorry to hear that. What's wrong?

dialogue.speaker: B

title: Elementary - Im sorry I love you 3
description: Learn im sorry i love you 3 through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Steven! Where have you been? I've been trying to get a hold of you for hours!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I... um... there was an emergency at work, so...

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you in the restaurant for three hours! And you didn't even have the decency to call me! Do you have any idea how embarrassed I was?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Honey, I promise this won't happen again, it's just that I...

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Yeah, right. I've heard it all before. I'm not going to take any more of your empty promises. This is the fifth time you've stood me up in two weeks! You need to get your priorities straight. I'm tired of you putting your job first all the time!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Come on, Veronica, that's not fair. I do care about you a lot, you know that. I tried to ...

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: You know what? Maybe we should just take a break. I need some time to think about where this relationship is heading.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: But...Veronica, would you just listen to me? There was a fire alarm at my office building today and I was stuck...

description: Learn im sorry i love you 1 through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Whoa, whoa, what's going on? Watch out!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hey, watch where you're going!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Oh, no! I'm so sorry! Are you all right?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh...I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I feel terrible, I really didn't mean to knock you over. My tire, just exploded, and I lost control of my bike. Really, it was an accident. Please accept my apologies.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Just let me try to stand up.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Are you okay?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh, wait a second, you seem really familiar, I think I know you from somewhere.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Yeah, I think we have met somewhere before. That's right! We met at Aaron's place last weekend! What a coincidence! But anyway, I'm glad to see that you're not too badly hurt, and I should probably get going. I have a nine o'clock meeting.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ouch! My ankle! I think it's broken! You can't just leave me like this! Are you calling an ambulance?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Nope, I'm canceling my appointment so that I can stay here with you.

vocabulary.definition: Sorry
Intend, plan
Suddenly break apart
An event that is not planed or intended
Probably known, but not clearly remembered
House
Situation when two or more things happen at the same time in an unplanned way
Make something fall over
Feel sad or sorry about something
Feeling or showing regret, showing an apology
Feel responsible for doing something bad
Not familiar
Falling in love the first time you see someone

title: Elementary - Learning Simple Math
description: Learn learning simple math through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hey, Gary, great to see you again. Please have a seat. So tell me, what seems to be the problem?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Thanks, doc. I've got a really bad toothache! I can't eat anything, and look, my face is all swollen. I think it might be my wisdom tooth.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, let's have a look. Open wide. Hmm... this doesn't look good. Well, it looks like you have a cavity and your crown is loose. We'll need to put in a filling before it gets any worse, and the crown probably needs to be refitted. I'm going to order some x-rays.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Is it gonna hurt?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: No, not at all! Just lay back and relax.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ok, spit.

Some parts are bigger than others due to a certain disease

title: Elementary - Baseball
description: Learn baseball through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hello baseball fans, and welcome back to today's game! My name is Rick Fields and of course, I am here, once again, with the man that seals the deal, Bob Copeland.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: It's a beautiful day to see two world class teams face each other and fight for their right to be called champions.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, the national anthem has just been sung, and the umpire has started the game. It's time to play ball!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Roger Vargas is up at bat. The pitcher winds up and strike one!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: A very nice curve ball by the pitcher. The catcher gives him the sign, he winds up and Vargas gets a line drive!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: The players are scrambling to get the ball. Vargas gets to first base and he's still going! The outfielder throws it to second! Vargas slides! He's safe!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Great play!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: We have a runner on third and up at bat is Brian Okami! There's the pitch, he hits it! It's going, going, that ball is gone!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Home run by Okami! That puts this team ahead by two as we are at the bottom of the fifth inning here at Richie Stadium!

title: Elementary - Difficult Customer
description: Learn difficult customer through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Good evening. My name is Fabio. I'll be your waiter for tonight. May I take your order?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: No, I'm still working on it. This menu isn't even in English. What's good here?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: For you sir, I would recommend  spaghetti and meatballs.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Does it come with coke and fries?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: It comes with either soup or salad and a complimentary glass of wine, sir.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'll go with the spaghetti and meatballs, salad and the wine.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Excellent choice. Your order will be ready soon.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: How soon is soon?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Twenty minutes?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You know what? I'll just go grab a burger across the street.

title: Elementary - Calling in Sick
description: Learn calling in sick through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hello, Daniel speaking, how may I help you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hi, Daniel, Julie here.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hi, Julie, how are you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Actually, I'm feeling quite ill today.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I'm sorry to hear that. What's wrong?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I think I'm coming down with the flu.  I have a headache, a sore throat a runny nose and I'm feeling slightly feverish.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I see... so you're calling in sick?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, I was hoping to take the day off to recover.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: OK, then. Try and get some rest.

title: Elementary - Hotel Upgrade
description: Learn hotel upgrade through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Good afternoon. What can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'd like to check in please. I have a reservation under the name Anthony Roberts.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: All right R.O.B.E.R.T.S... Oh, Mr. Roberts we've been expecting you… and here is your keycard to the presidential suite.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: But there must be some mistake; my reservation was for a standard room.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Are you sure? Let me double check .

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah…Here, this is my confirmation number.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: You're right Mr. Roberts, there seems to be a mix-up, unfortunately we're overbooked at the moment .

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: So…

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Not to worry. We're pleased to offer you a complimentary upgrade.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Presidential suite baby!

title: Elementary - I need an assistant
description: Learn i need an assistant through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: ...like I told you before, we just don't have the resources to hire you an assistant.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I understand that, but the fact is we're understaffed.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: The timing is just not right. The economy is bad, and it's too risky to take on new staff.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, I guess you're right.... here's an idea, what if we hire an intern? She would take some of the weight off my shoulders.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: She?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, you know, a recent graduate. She could give me a hand with some of these projects and we could keep our costs down.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That sounds reasonable... let me see what I can do.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Tony, I'd like to introduce you to your new assistant.

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh... hi... I'm Tony...

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yup, I think so. The car's packed; we have munchies and music, and the map's in the car.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Did you get the camera?

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Yup, it's all set.

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: B

title: Elementary - Virus
description: Learn virus through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Oh great! This stupid computer froze again! That’s the third time today! Hey Samuel, can you come take a look at my PC? It’s acting up again. It must have a virus or something.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Just give me a second; I’ll be right up.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I ran a virus scan on your computer, and it turns out that you have a lot of infected files!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: But I’m quite careful when I’m browsing the internet, I have no idea how I could have picked up a virus.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, you have to make sure that your anti-virus software is updated regularly; yours wasn't up to date, that's probably what was causing your problems.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ok. Anything else?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, try not to kick or hit the computer!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Um yeah… Sorry about that.

title: Elementary - What is your name again
description: Learn what is your name again through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Nick! How's it going?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh, hey...

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: What are you doing in this neightbourhood? Do you live around here?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Actually, my office is right around the corner.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: It was great to meet you last week at the conference. I really enjoyed our conversation about foreign investment.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah, it was really interesting. You know, I'm in a bit of a hurry, but here's my card. We should definitely meet up again and continue our discussion.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sure, you still have my contact details, right ?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You know what, this is really embarrassing, but your name has just slipped my mind. Can you remind me?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sure, my name is Ana Ferris. Don't worry about it; it happens to me all the time. I'm terrible with names too.

title: Intermediate - Driving Sales
description: Learn driving sales through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: All right, people. We're holding this meeting today because we've got to do something about our sales, and we need to do it NOW! I want concrete solutions. How do you intend to drive sales... Roger?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, in fact, we're the most expensive in the market, so maybe we need to lower our prices to match the competitors?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Lower our prices? Not very creative. It'll never fly with Swan. What kind of thinking is that? Geez. Anybody else have a better plan? Natalie?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: What? That's the same thing. Bad idea. Really bad idea. Dammit people come on! Think! The CEO will be here any minute.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Yeah, exactly. Just what I was thinking! In fact, that's a brilliant idea! I'm glad we thought of that. Very creative.

title: Upper - Intermediate New Guy in Town
description: Learn intermediate new guy in town through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Oh, I don't know if you heard, but someone moved into that old house down the road.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, I know. I met the owner of the house yesterday as he was moving in. His name is Armand.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Really? What's he like? You have to fill me in.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Actually, he's a bit strange. I don't know... I've got a bad feeling about him.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Really? Why?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, yesterday I brought over a housewarming gift, but Armand started acting really weird, and then he practically kicked me out! I tried to, sort of, peek into his house, but everything was so dark inside that I couldn't really get a good look.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, you'll never guess what I saw this morning. A delivery truck pulled into his driveway, and it dropped off a long, rectangular box. It almost looked like a coffin!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You see! Why would he...

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ah, Armand! You scared the heck out of me! This is my friend Doris.

vocabulary.definition: Phrase used to introduce a piece of information

title: Intermediate - Cleaning the House
description: Learn cleaning the house through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Honey, the house is such a mess! I need you to help me tidy up a bit. My boss and her husband are coming over for dinner and the house needs to be spotless!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'm in the middle of something right now. I'll be there in a second.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: This can't wait! I need your help now!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Alright, alright. I'm coming.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ok, here's a list of chores we need to get done. I'll do the dishes and get all the groceries for tonight. You can sweep and mop the floors. Oh, and the furniture needs to be dusted.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You know what, I have to pick something up at the mall, so why don't you clean the floors and I’ll go to the supermarket and get all the groceries.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sure that's fine. Here is the list of all the things you need to get. Don’t forget anything! And can you pick up a bottle of wine on your way home?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hey, honey I'm back. Wow, the house looks really good!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Great! Can you set the table?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Just a sec I'm just gonna vacuum this rug real fast

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Wait! Don't turn it on...

title: Intermediate - Out of Control Spending
description: Learn out of control spending through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: OK, so now the last point on our agenda. Jill, let's go over the profit and loss statement.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Great. Well, the main issue here, as you can see, is that our expenses are through the roof.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Let's see... These numbers are off the charts! What's going on here!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, um, sir, the company expenditures on entertainment and travel are out of control. Look at these bills for example. Just this month we've paid over twenty thousand dollars for hotel charges!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: OK, thank you. I'll look into it.

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: B

title: Intermediate - Im sorry I love you 1
description: Learn im sorry i love you 1 through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Whoa, whoa, what's going on? Watch out!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hey, watch where you're going!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Oh, no! I'm so sorry! Are you all right?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh...I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I feel terrible, I really didn't mean to knock you over. My tire, just exploded, and I lost control of my bike. Really, it was an accident. Please accept my apologies.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Just let me try to stand up.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Are you okay?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh, wait a second, you seem really familiar, I think I know you from somewhere.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Yeah, I think we have met somewhere before. That's right! We met at Aaron's place last weekend! What a coincidence! But anyway, I'm glad to see that you're not too badly hurt, and I should probably get going. I have a nine o'clock meeting.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ouch! My ankle! I think it's broken! You can't just leave me like this! Are you calling an ambulance?

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: OK, make a left here...no wait, I meant make a right. Come on speed up!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Geeze! What's the rush?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Don't worry about it, just drive. Oh, no, the light is about to change... step on it!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Are you nuts? I'm not going to run a red light!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Whatever. Just turn right here. The freeway will be packed at this hour.... let's take a side street. Go on! Get out of our way! Move, move!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What's your problem? Geez. Having a fit is not going to help!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Here, I know a short cut... just go down here and we'll cut through Ashburn Heights. Let's go, let's go! Watch out for that lady!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'm going as fast as I can!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Yes! We made it. 5:58, just before the library closes.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You're such a geek!

Crazy

Quickly go past or though something that blocks you

title: Elementary - Here Comes the Bride
description: Learn here comes the bride through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I can't believe that Anthony is finally getting married!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, well, it's about time. He's been living with his parents for forty years!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Don't be mean. Look, here come the bridesmaids! Their dresses look beautiful!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Who are those kids walking down the aisle?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That's the flower girl and the ring bearer. I'm pretty sure they're the groom's niece and nephew. Oh, they look so cute!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I just hope the priest makes it quick. I'm starving. I hope the food's good at the reception.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That’s all you ever think about, food! Oh, I think the bride's coming now! She looks gorgeous. Wait, what's she doing? Where's she going?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh, great! Does this mean that the reception is canceled?

vocabulary.definition: Joined in marriage

title: Upper - Intermediate Protest
description: Learn intermediate protest through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: This is Action 5 News reporter Sarah O'Connell reporting live from Washington, D. C. where a protest has broken out. Thousands of angry citizens are protesting against the proposed bailout of the auto manufacturing industry! Sir, sir, Sar

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah, we are here because we feel this is an injustice! The financial irresponsibility of big business has to stop! We're here to show the government that we don't like the way that they're spending our tax dolla

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sir, but what exactly is making everyone so angry?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: It's an absolute outrage, Sarah, the US government wants to give twenty-five billion dollars of taxpayers' money to the auto industry. These are companies that have been mismanaged and are now nearly bankrupt.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I see. But, many supporters of the bailout argue that it could help save the jobs of millions of hardworking Americans.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: That may be true, and I for one don't want to see anyone lose their job, but how can these CEOs ask for a bailout when they're making millions of dollars? And then they have the nerve to fly to Washington in private jets! This

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Good point. This is Sarah O'Connell reporting live from Washington D. C., back to you, Tom.

title: Intermediate - Christmas Chronicles 1
description: Learn christmas chronicles 1 through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I hate working on Christmas Eve! Whoa! Get a load of this guy! Come in central, I think we've got ourselves a situation here.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: License and registration please. Have you been drinking tonight, sir?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I had one or two glasses of eggnog, but nothing else.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Step out of the vehicle, please. Sir, what do you have in the back?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Just a few Christmas gifts, 'tis the season, after all!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Don't take that tone with me. Do you have an invoice for these items?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Umm...no...I make these in my workshop in the North Pole!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You are under arrest, sir. You have the right to remain silent. You better not pout, you better not cry. Anything you say can and will be used against you. You have the right to an attorney; if you cannot afford one, the state will appoint

title: Elementary - I can see clearly now
description: Learn i can see clearly now through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hello, Arthur. What seems to be the problem?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hey doc. Well, I think I might need glasses. I'm getting headaches, and I really struggle to see things that are far away. But I have always had 20/20 vision.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sounds like you may be far-sighted. OK, then, cover your left eye and read the chart in front of you.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Mmm… X, E, R, 3, a question mark, and I can't quite make out the other symbol but I think it's the peace sign.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Wow, Arthur! You're as blind as a bat!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, I know, my vision is really blurry at times.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ok, then, head on over to the other room and pick out some frames while I fill out your prescription.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Thanks, doc!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Arthur, that's the bathroom.

title: Elementary - Making an Appointment

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hello, Fairbrook Consulting, how may I help you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, this is Julianne Horton, and I'm calling to arrange an appointment with Ms. McNealy.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Certainly, what day were you thinking of?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: How's Thursday? Does she have any time available then?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Um... let me double check...unfortunately, she's booked solid on Thursday, how does next Monday work for you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Actually, I've got something scheduled on Monday. Can she do Tuesday?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sure, Tuesday's perfect. May I ask where you're calling from?

title: Upper - Intermediate Planning for the Worst
description: Learn intermediate planning for the worst through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, right, let’s move to our next order of business, as many of you are aware, in recent weeks there has been a lot of media coverage surrounding this bird flu issue. And it's come to my attention that our company lacks any sort of bird flu c

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Basically, we need to come up with a clear plan; we need to outline specific actions that our company can take to maintain critical business functions in case a pandemic strikes.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: So, what I’d like to do is: first appoint someone to look after drafting our plan; Ralph, I’d like you to head up this project.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, let’s see, there are a few points we need to be thinking about... first, I’ll need you to analyze our numbers and figure out what kind of financial impact an outbreak might have.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: You’ll also need to think about how we can avoid any of our employees getting infected; think of ways to reduce employee-customer contact, perhaps some IT solutions that will allow our people to work from home.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Exactly right. So, I’ll leave this to you, and we’ll review the draft plan in two weeks. Okay, so, anyone want to order some KFC for lunch?

Lead and be responsible for
Predict what is going to happen based on available information

title: Elementary - New Year Resolution

dialogue.text: So, did I tell you about my New Year's resolution? I've decided to go on a diet.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: And you're going to completely transform your eating habits, right?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Exactly! I'm going to cut out all that junk I eat; no more chips, no more soda, no more fried food.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I've heard this one before.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: But this time I'm going to stick to it. I really mean it! Trust me, Carol, I'm going to be a new man in one year's time!

dialogue.speaker: B

title: Elementary - Asking for time Off
description: Learn asking for time off through this lesson.

dialogue.text: Mr. McKenna, do you have a second? I need to talk to you about something.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure, Liv, what can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, I was just wondering... you see, I know I've used up all my vacation days this year, but my sister is getting married, and the wedding is overseas, and, well...

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You wanna take some time off, is that right?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, sir, I was just hoping that I might be able to take some unpaid leave this year.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What dates are you planning on taking off? I'll need at least two months notice, so that I can plan for your absence.

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I guess so.

title: Intermediate - Opening a Bank Account
description: Learn opening a bank account through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Next, please. May I help you, sir?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hello, yes, I'd like to open a bank account.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Certainly, I can can help you with that. What type of account would you like to open? A chequing or a savings account?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What What features do they offer?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, if you just take a look here, see, with our chequing account, you can have unlimited daily transactions for a small monthly fee, and our savings account has a higher interest rate, but you must carry a minimum balance of $ 10,000 dollars.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I see, well, I think I'm more interested in a chequing account; I like to have easy access to my money.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Alright, then, with this chequing account you'll be issued a debit card and a cheque book. Will you require overdraft protection? There is an extra fee for that.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: No, that won't be necessary.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: In that case, I'll get you to fill out this paperwork; I'll need your social insurance number, and two pieces of government ID. If you could just sign here, and here, and here; we'll be all set. Would you like to make a deposit today?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, I'd like to deposit one billion dollars.

title: Upper - Intermediate Live from Washington
description: Learn intermediate live from washington through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: This is Madeline Wright, for BCC News reporting live from Washington D. C. where, very shortly, the new President will deliver his inaugural address. Just moments ago, the President was sworn in to office; following the United States Constitution the president swore an oath to faithfully execute the office of the presidency.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: And what exactly is going on now, Madeline?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, Tom, true to American tradition, the band has just played Hail to the Chief, and the President has been honored by a 21 gun salute. Now we're waiting for the President to take to the stage and deliver his speech. Tom, it's like a who's who of the political world here on Capital Hill, with dignitaries representing several different countries.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What's the mood on the ground like, Madeline?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: In a word, the mood here is electric. The excitement in the air is palpable; I've never seen a larger crowd here on Capital Hill, and the audience is shouting crying, and embracing each other. On this, a most historic day, you can feel the hope and the excitement in the air. The twentieth of January will go down in history as the... Oh, Tom, it looks like the President is about to to begin...

title: Intermediate - Hes not a good fit
description: Learn hes not a good fit through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: So, Lauren, I just wanted to talk to you quickly about our new customer support representative, Jason Huntley.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure, what's up?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Basically, I've got a few concerns about him, and the bottom line is, I don't think he's a good fit for our company.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Okay... what makes you say that? I thought you were pleased with his overall performance. Didn't you just tell me last week how impressed you were with his attitude?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Yeah, his attitude is great, but he's really unreliable. Sometimes he's really productive, but then other times... take last Tuesday for instance, he was forty-five minutes late for our morning meeting!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I'm sure he had a perfectly good reason...

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: But that's not the only thing... you know, he really doesn't have the best work ethic, I'm constantly catching him on MSN and Facebook when he should be talking to clients.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, but come on, Geoff, as if you don't check Facebook at work. Look, you hired this guy, we've invested a lot of time and money in his training, so now it's up to you to coach him. Make it work, Geoff!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Make it work, Geoff. You would say that, wouldn't you, he is your cousin; what a jerk, make me hire your stupid, useless, cousin.

title: Elementary - Im sorry I love you 3

dialogue.speaker: A

title: Intermediate - Applying for a Visa
description: Learn applying for a visa through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: So, you're applying for a B2 visa, where is your final destination and what's the purpose of your trip to the United States?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'm going to visit my brother; he's just had a baby. He lives in Minneapolis.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: And how long do you you plan to remain in the United States?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'll be here for approximately three weeks. See, here's my return ticket for the twenty-sixth of March.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: And, who is sponsoring your trip?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: My brother, here, this is an invitation letter from him. I will stay with him and his family in their home.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Alright, tell me about the ties you have to your home country.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I own a house; actually, I'm leaving my dog there with my neighbors. I have a car at home, and oh, my job! I'm employed by Tornel as an engineer. Actually, I only have three weeks' vacation, so I have to go back to work at the end of March.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: And what evidence do you have that you are financially independent?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I do have assets in my country; like I said, I own a house, and see, here's a bank statement showing my investments, and my bank balance.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, sir, we cannot grant you a B2 visa at this time, instead, you are granted a resident visa! Congratulations, you are the millionth person to apply for a visa! You win! Congratulations!

title: Advanced - Just in Time Strategy
description: Learn just in time strategy through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I called this meeting today in order to discuss our manufacturing plan. As I'm sure you're all aware, with the credit crunch, and the global financial crisis, we're obligated to look for more cost efficient ways of producing our goods. We don't want to have to be looking at redundancies. So, we've outlined a brief plan to implement the just-in-time philosophy.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: We have two basic points that we want to focus on. First of all, we want to reduce our lead time.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, we want to reduce production and delivery lead timesfor better overall efficiency.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Right, production lead times can be reduced by moving work stations closer together, reducing queue length, like for example, reducing the number of jobs waiting to be processed at a given machine, and improving the coordination and cooperation between successive processes. Delivery lead times can be reduced through close cooperation with suppliers, possibly by inducing suppliers to locate closer to the factory or working with a faster shipping company.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: The second point is that we want to require supplier quality assurance and implement a zero defects quality program. We currently have far too many errors that lead to defective items and therefore, they must be eliminated. A quality control at the source program must be implemented to give workers the personal responsibility for the quality of the work they do, and the authority to stop production when something goes wrong.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Exactly. Well, let's look at how we're going to put this plan into action. First...(fade out)

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ok. Hurry up take the picture!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh really.... no I can't. No really, I don't know how to dance! Honey I'll see you later!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Patrick! Don't just leave me here!

title: Intermediate - Daddy Please
description: Learn daddy please through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hey daddy! You look great today; I like your tie! By the way, I was wondering can I…

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: NO!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I haven’t even told you what it is yet!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Okay, okay, what do you want?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Do you think I could borrow the car? I'm going to a concert tonight.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Um.. I don't think so. I need the car tonight to pick up your mother.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ugg! I told you about it last week! Smelly Toes is playing, and Eric asked if I would go with him!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Who’s this Eric guy?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Duh! He’s like the hottest and most popular guy at school! Come on, dad! Please!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: No can do... sorry.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Fine then! Would you mind giving me 100 bucks?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: No way!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That's so unfair!

title: Intermediate - New Guy in Town 3

dialogue.speaker: A

title: Elementary - What a Bargain
description: Learn what a bargain through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hello. May I help you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, this dress is really nice! How much is it?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That one is one hundred and fifty dollars.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: One hundred and fifty dollars? What about this other one over here?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That's one hundred and forty dollars.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hmm...that's a bit out of my price range. Can you give me a better deal?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: This is an exclusive design by DaMarco! It's a bargain at that price.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I don't know. I think I'll shop around.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, okay, how about one hundred dollars?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: That's still more than I wanted to spend. What if I take both dresses?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, I can give you a special discount, just because you seem like a nice person. One hundred and ninety dollars for both.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I don't know... It's still a bit pricey.... Thanks anyway.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, my final price! One hundred dollars for both! That's two for the price of one. That's my last offer!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Great! You've got a deal!

title: Elementary - Pizza Delivery
description: Learn pizza delivery through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Good evening, Pizza House. This is Marty speaking. May I take your order?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Um yes… I’d like a medium pizza with pepperoni, olives, and extra cheese.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: We have a two-for-one special on large pizzas. Would you like a large pizza instead?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure, that sounds good.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Great! Would you like your second pizza to be the same as the first?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: No, make the second one with ham, pineapple and green peppers. Oh, and make it thin crust.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, thin crust. Your total is $21.50 and your order will arrive in thirty minutes or it's free!

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.text: Jean Pierre another special! We're really packed tonight! We're running low on wine. Is there any left in the cellar?

dialogue.speaker: B

title: Intermediate - Im sorry I love you 5
description: Learn im sorry i love you 5 through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Honey, of course I forgive you! I love you so much! I've really missed you. I was wrong to get upset over nothing.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'm sorry I haven't called or anything, but right after you decided you wanted a break, I was called up north to put out some major forest fires! I was in the middle of nowhere, working day and night, trying to prevent the blaze from spreading! It was pretty intense.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Oh, honey, I'm glad you're okay! But I have some exciting news... I think I'm pregnant!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Really? Wow, that's amazing! This is great news! I've always wanted to be a father! We'll go to the doctor first thing in the morning!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Are you sure? Are these things accurate?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: What's wrong? Why are you asking these questions?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: This baby isn't mine! I was away the first week of February at a training seminar!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I... I... no, it can't be...

title: Intermediate - Hockey

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That's right, and it looks like we're just about ready to start the match. The ref is calling the players for the face-off... and here we go! The Russians win possession and immediately set up their attack! Federov gets checked hard into the boards!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Maurice Richard has the puck now, and passes it to the center. He shoots! Wow what a save by the goalie!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Alright, the puck is back in play now. Pavel Bure is on a breakaway! He is flying down the ice! The defenders can't keep up! Slap shot! He scores

dialogue.speaker: B

title: Intermediate - Planning a Bank Robbery
description: Learn planning a bank robbery through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: All right, so this is what we are going to do. I've carefully mapped this out, so don't screw it up. Mr. Rabbit, you and Mr. Fox will go into the bank wearing these uniforms. We managed to get replicas of the one the guards wear when they pick up the money.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Got it.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: When you get inside, tell them that you are filling in for Carl and Tom, and say that they are on another route today. Don't lose your cool. Just act natural.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What if they want to call and confirm?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: You let him.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Don’t worry, we have the phones tapped, so the call will be patched through to me, and I’ll pretend to be the transport company.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ha ha, you are so clever boss!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, shut up. Only take as much money as you can fit in these bags. Don’t get greedy! Are you ready? Let's go.

title: Advanced - Job Interview 1
description: Learn job interview 1 through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, so let's go over everything one more time. I really want you to get this job!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I know! It's an amazing growth opportunity! They're true industry leaders, and it would be so interesting to be part of an organization that is the undisputed leader in business process platform development.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: So, let's see, you did your research on the company, right?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I visited their website and read up on what they do. They're an IT service company that offers comprehensive business solutions for large corporations. They provide services such as CRM development, and they also offer custom-designed applications.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: So what would your role in the company?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, the position is for an account manager. That basically means that I would be the link between our and our development team.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sounds good, and so, why do you want to work with them?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, as I said they're the industry leaders, they have a really great growth strategy, amazing development opportunities for employees, and it seems like they have strong corporate governance. They're all about helping companies grow and unleashing potential. I guess their core values and mission really resonated with me. Oh, and they offer six weeks' vacation, stock options and bonuses... I'm totally going to cash in on that.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: You idiot! Don't say that! Do you want this job, or not?

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, you gotta admit, my acting was brilliant!

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Run!

title: Elementary - Swim faster

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: This is such a beautiful day! Great for sailing!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: It sure is! The water looks so nice! Anchor the boat for a little while. I'm going to take a dip.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Why are you doggy-paddling? I taught you how to swim! Do your breast stroke!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I get too tired! I'll just backstroke, it's easier!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Try kicking your legs more. That's good. Don't go out too far!

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A
