title: 195 - Job Hunting
description: Learn job hunting through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Woo hoo! This just might be the start of the rest of my life!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What happened?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I'm in the market for a job! I went on a website with hundreds of job listings in the area and browsed through them until I got the names of a few employers I would like to work for. I have the resume I wrote for English class last month and a cover letter will be a piece of cake to write. I've even done my research and found the names of the managers so I can address the letters personally. And you know I can be charming in interviews. Goodbye my penniless days! Hello salary and a career!

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: A

title: 198 - Applying CPR
description: Learn applying cpr through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hello everyone and welcome to our CPR for beginners course. First of all, does anyone know what CPR stands for?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That's right! We apply CPR in the case of cardiac arrest or pulmonary arrest.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What does that mean?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, basically if your heart stops pumping blood, or your lungs stop pumping air, then we need to get them going again! That's when we have to apply this procedure. Let's begin! I need a volunteer.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Me! Me!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Alright, come here and lay flat on your back. Let's suppose this young woman has stopped breathing. We must lift the person's chin so that we clear a pathway for air to get into the lungs. Then we place our mouth over the other person's mouth and blow air two or three times, like this.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Wait, what are you doing? I'm a married woman! You can't just try to kiss me like this!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ma’ am I'm not trying to kiss you! I am trying to demonstrate how to apply CPR in the case of an emergency.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, ok. But no French kissing!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: As I was saying, we blow air through the mouth in this manner. Once this is done, we must try to get the heart going again. To do this, we place our hands over the person's chest, and press down firmly two or three times.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Wait, what are you doing! You can't just kiss me then go for second base!

title: 199 - Learning About First Aid
description: Learn learning about first aid through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hey Joe! Where have you been these past few days?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I've been busy with a first aid course that I started about a week ago at the Red Cross.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Cool! I've always wanted to do something like that! Have you learned anything useful?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: For sure! I mean we've learned how to apply pressure to stop bleeding, how to check for a pulse, and even how to apply CPR!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Have you treated any real emergencies?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, they took us along with some paramedics. There was this guy who fell off his motorcycle and suffered a concussion as well as a couple of compound fractures. His wounds were pretty serious so they had to rush him to the hospital. It was intense!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I can imagine! I tend to faint when I see blood, so I think I won't be taking up a course like that anytime soon!

title: Advanced - Movie Review
description: Learn movie review through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Welcome back movie lovers to another " Premier Movie Review". My name is Richard Clarke and I am joined today by the very erudite David Watson.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Thank you Dick. Today we are going to talk about the movie " Lion King". Tell me Dave, what is your impression of this film?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, I think this film is simply a fable, depicting man's eternal greed for power, and in my opinion, it's a very fine film. Even despite the accusations of plagiarism traditional folk tales from other countries. The musical score was amazing, the animation was very well done, and the story was simply enchanting.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I think otherwise. Even though the animation was technically strong, and as you say, the score and songs performed by Elton John were great, the film lacks a certain originality; it lacked heart. And I would dare to say, it was too predictable.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Predictable! How! Come on Dick, It's a G-rated movie! It's for the kids! It's not a thriller!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, that's just it. It did have some very dramatic and intense scenes For example when Mufasa dies, or the dark, grim portrayal of Scar. Even so, the film is linear. Mufasa dies, Simba runs away thinking it's his fault. Falls in love and returns to retake what is rightfully his. It's just too cliché.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: How can it be cliché? It's a fable! It's telling a time-honoured story! The movie make a point of how the hunger for power leads to corruption, and teaches children the value of respect, life and love.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You have always been so soft, Dave!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Open your heart Dick. Don't shut us out.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Anyway... That's all for today folks! Join us next time as we talk about "How to lose a guy in 10 days" I'm sure you'll love that one Dave!

title: Advanced - Big Bang Theory
description: Learn big bang theory through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: What's up? You don't look too good.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, my head hurts, that's all. I've been in physics class all day. It's killer!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I liked physics. It's all math, really; arcs, curves, velocity, cool stuff.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah, but today's lesson was all about the creation of the universe.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: A physics class about the creation of the universe? That's some pretty unscientific language there. Sounds more religous to me.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: It's all religion. Take the theory of the Big Bang. How is it possible that all of the stuff in the universe comes from an explosion? That's no better than Atlas carrying the globe on his back or African myths about turtles and stuff.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Turtles? Whatever... Look, all that's required for the creation of matter an imbalance of particles and anti-particles. At least, that's what the math says.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Math, shmath. What's the evidence?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: There is evidence! You know Edwin Hubble? He's the guy who in the early twentieth century was the first scientist to measure the drift of matter in the universe, thus advancing notions of an expanding universe. What would it be expanding from? Well, the Big Bang... DUH!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Anyway, it's just a theory. Why do people go around touting theories? Where's the scientific rigor in that?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Dude, don't equivocate. A theory only becomes a theory after withstanding rigorous testing. You slept through class, didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Agh! You're making my head hurt again! Quit with the questions!

title: Advanced - Job Interview 1

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, so let's go over everything one more time. I really want you to get this job!

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: So, let's see, you did your research on the company, right?

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: So what would your role in the company?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, the position is for an account manager. That basically means that I would be the link between our and our development team.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sounds good, and so, why do you want to work with them?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, as I said they're the industry leaders, they have a really great growth strategy, amazing development opportunities for employees, and it seems like they have strong corporate governance. They're all about helping companies grow and unleashing potential. I guess their core values and mission really resonated with me. Oh, and they offer six weeks' vacation, stock options and bonuses... I'm totally going to cash in on that.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: You idiot! Don't say that! Do you want this job, or not?

title: Advanced - Just in Time Strategy
description: Learn just in time strategy through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I called this meeting today in order to discuss our manufacturing plan. As I'm sure you're all aware, with the credit crunch, and the global financial crisis, we're obligated to look for more cost efficient ways of producing our goods. We don't want to have to be looking at redundancies. So, we've outlined a brief plan to implement the just-in-time philosophy.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: We have two basic points that we want to focus on. First of all, we want to reduce our lead time.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, we want to reduce production and delivery lead timesfor better overall efficiency.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Right, production lead times can be reduced by moving work stations closer together, reducing queue length, like for example, reducing the number of jobs waiting to be processed at a given machine, and improving the coordination and cooperation between successive processes. Delivery lead times can be reduced through close cooperation with suppliers, possibly by inducing suppliers to locate closer to the factory or working with a faster shipping company.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: The second point is that we want to require supplier quality assurance and implement a zero defects quality program. We currently have far too many errors that lead to defective items and therefore, they must be eliminated. A quality control at the source program must be implemented to give workers the personal responsibility for the quality of the work they do, and the authority to stop production when something goes wrong.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Exactly. Well, let's look at how we're going to put this plan into action. First...(fade out)

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Welcome back racing fans! My name is Rick Fields and, as always, I am joined by my partner in crime, Bob Copeland.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: We're in the last stretch of this very exciting race, and Kimi Räikkönen is leading the pack with only four laps to go! They are heading to turn three and Lewis Hamilton tries to pass Räikkönen! It's a close one and, oh no! Hamilton hits the wall!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: He came in too fast, jammed on the breaks and spun out. We have a yellow flag and the pace car is making its way onto the track.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: The cleanup crew is towing the heavily damaged car and the green flag drops! Räikkönen is still in the lead with only two laps to go!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Smoke is coming out of his car! He seems to be having engine trouble! He makes his way into the pit, and Fernando Alonso takes the lead!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: How unlucky for Räikkönen, and this race is over ladies and gentlemen, Alonso takes the checkered flag!

title: Advanced - Job Interview 3
description: Learn job interview 3 through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Very good. Now, I have a couple of final questions.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I hope they're not too hard!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, why should we hire you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I think that I would be a perfect fit in this company. I have a unique combination of strong technical acumen, and outstanding soft skills; you know, I excel at building strong, long-term customer relationships. For example, when I headed the customer support department in my previous company, our team solved about seventy percent of our customers' problems. I decided that we needed better information and technical preparation on our products, so after I implemented a series of training sessions in coordination with our technical department, we were able to solve ninety percent of our customers' issues. Given the opportunity, I could bring this kind of success to this company.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Impressive! So, what would you consider to be your greatest weakness?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: To be honest, I struggle with organization and time management. Punctuality has never been a strength of mine. I find it hard to organize my time efficiently. I have actually addressed this weakness recently, by attending a workshop on efficient time management. It helped me a lot, by providing me with great insights on how to get organized and use my time efficiently, so I think I'm getting better now.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Great... Well, let me tell you that I am very pleased with this interview. We are short-listing our candidates this week, and next week we will inform our short listed candidates of the day and time for a second interview with our CEO.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Great, thanks a lot! I hope to hear from you! Good bye.

title: Advanced - Job Interview 2
description: Learn job interview 2 through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Thanks for coming in today, did you have any trouble finding us? Please take a seat.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: So, let's get started; tell me a bit about your educational background.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure! Well, I graduated with honors from Chesterton University with a major in Business Administration, with a specialization in Information Management, and I minored in psychology. I chose this course of study for two reasons: I wanted to gain some practical, marketable skills, which the information management track provided, and I also feel that interpersonal skills are essential for professional success, hence the minor in psychology.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Interesting. And, your postgraduate studies?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I am really passionate about consumer behavior, so I pursued a master's in that area. I also strive to keep my professional skills current, so I continuously attend seminars and conferences related management and customer service.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Very good. Now, tell me a little bit about your work experience. I see here that you previously worked at Oracle.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, I worked as their customer support manager, which brought me a breadth of experience in both client care, and process management. I supervised and coordinated the customer support team as well as implemented new strategies to achieve better customer satisfaction.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Interesting...

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, in this position I was able to make some pretty significant contributions to the overall success of the company. With the different initiatives that we implemented, we lowered our churn rate to about five percent, which had a direct impact on revenue.

title: Advanced - Investing in Emerging Markets
description: Learn investing in emerging markets through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Dad, I'd like to borrow some money.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure, Johnny, how much do you need? Five bucks?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Come on, Dad, I need thirty thousand. I wanna get into the market. You know, I'm tired of hearing all this news about the economic downturn, the inevitable recession, people stuffing their money in their mattresse

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I don't know about that; with all the uncertainty in the market right now, it would be a very unwise decision to invest. I don't know if you're aware son, but there has been a lot of turmoil in the markets recentl

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: But look at it this way, every challenge is an opportunity. And anyway, I'm not talking about investing in the domestic market. There are emerging markets that promise great returns. Look at China, for example; th

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Come on son, you're looking at this too naively, the Chinese market has exhibited a great deal of instability, and their currency has been devalued by almost a whole percentage point.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Fine, then! If that's the way you feel, so be it. But you're losing out on a great opportunity here. I'm going to go hit up Mom for the cash.

vocabulary.definition: Unavoidable
Money that is saved to pay for something in the future, usually a house, or retirement
A state of confusion, disorder, disturbance
Amount of money the government uses to improve the economy
State of not being stable, being likely to change
Nations undergoing quick industrialization
Combined
Reduced in value
Ask for money
An decrease in the value of something
An increase in the value of something
An continual increase in price
Growing economy
Countries undergoing quick industrialization
Nations that have developed factories and businesses

title: Intermediate - Where are you from
description: Learn where are you from through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Where to, miss?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hi! Crenshaw and Hawthorne, at the Holiday Inn that is on that corner.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sure thing. So, where are you flying in from?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: From China.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Really? You don't look very Chinese to me, if you don't mind me saying so.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: It's fine. I am actually from Mexico. I was in China on a business trip, visiting some local companies that manufacture bathroom products.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Wow sounds interesting! Excuse me if I am being a bit nosy but, how old are you?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Don't you know it's rude to ask a lady her age?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Don't get me wrong! It's just that you seem so young and already doing business overseas!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well thank you! In that case, I am 26 years old, and what about yourself?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I am 40 years old and was born and raised here in the good old U.S of A, although I have some Colombian heritage.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Really? That's great! Do you speak some Spanish?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Uh... yeah.. of course!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Que bien! Entonces podemos hablar en espanol!

vocabulary.word: If you don't mind me saying so (phrase)
vocabulary.definition: A polite phrase to use where you are saying something sensitive
Arrive
Too interested in others' private matters
Because of that
Do not misunderstand me
Where would you like to go
In foreign countries
To live in a place your whole life

vocabulary.word: The good old U.S of A (phrase)
vocabulary.definition: The United States
That subject is too personal (impolite)
Phrase you use when you don't want to answer a question
Too much information
About a person's private thoughs, feelings, etc.
To look for private information about someone

title: Intermediate - Flattering
description: Learn flattering through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Valerie! Hi! Wow how are you? It's been such a long time!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Darlene! Indeed, it's been a while! How have you been? Wow, you look amazing! I love what you've done with your hair!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Really? Thanks! I went to that hair salon that you told me about, but enough about me! Look at you! You haven't aged a day since the last time I saw you! What is your secret!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ha ha, come on! Well, I've been watching what I eat, and working out three times a week. By the way, I heard your son recently graduated!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Yes, my little Paul is finally a doctor. They grow up so fast you know.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: He is such a handsome guy. He gets his looks from his mother of course!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Thank you! What about your daughter, Pamela? I heard she has passed the bar exam and married recently.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh yes. She had a beautiful wedding in Cozumel Mexico and we all attended.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Such a lovely girl. I hope my Paul is lucky enough to find a girl like that someday!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: But of course! Well, it's been great talking to you, but I have to get going.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Same here! We will catch up soon, maybe over coffee!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: That would be great! Give me a call!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: See you soon! Bye! Ugg... I can't stand that woman or her obnoxious son.

vocabulary.word: I love what you have done with (phrase)
vocabulary.definition: I really like the design or the change you made
You haven't gotten older; you look young
Do physical exercises
Phrase used to shift to another topic
The exam to qualify as a lawer
Leave
Really annoying
Short, friendly, unimportant conversations
Speak badly of someone with out them knowing
Pretend to like someone when you don't; be hypocritical
Do something unkind to a friend
Talk about the details of other people's lives

title: Intermediate - 1960s English
description: Learn 1960s english through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hey man... I really like your pad. Those lava lamps are far out! Thanks for letting me crash here tonight.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: It's no problem, brother! I wanted a pad where people could come, listen to music and just hang loose, you dig what I'm saying?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I dig it man! We could throw a bash here and make it a really happening scene!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah man, that would be groovy! Hey, I gotta split for a while, are you OK here by yourself?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Don't worry about me brother... You go take care of business.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Alright, peace out.

The latest, cool

title: Intermediate - Talking About a Past Event
description: Learn talking about a past event through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Mike! Hey, how are you, man! Long time no see!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hey, Pat! Yeah, I haven't seen you in ages! How are you?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I'm doing great! It's funny running into you like this. Just last week I ran into Matt as well.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah? How's he doing?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: He's doing well. We went out for a couple of beers and the funniest thing happened.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh yeah?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, we were talking and catching up on what we've been doing, talking about work and family, when all of a sudden, Matt saw a mouse run under his chair and he completely lost it! He started freaking out, and screaming...

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ha ha, really?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Yeah, and the funniest thing was, that he jumped on to his chair and started shrieking like a girl. You had to be there! Everyone was staring and laughing... it was hilarious!

vocabulary.definition: A greeting phrase
An informal way of calling a person
A greeting phrase used after two friends have not seen each other for a long time
For a long time
A phrase you use to respond to a greeting
Meeting someone accidentally
Learn about recent past events
Show a lot of emotion; be not able to control emotions
Screaming in a very high voice
Look at something for a long time with great attention
Very amusing
Lose control of your emotions; show strong, negative emotions
Go crazy; lose control of yourself
A very fun time; or a funny event
Very silly or unreasonable

title: Intermediate - At The Airport
description: Learn at the airport through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Next please! Hello sir, may I see your passport please?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, here you go.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Will you be checking any bags.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, I'd like to check three pieces.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, sir. Airline policy allows only two pieces of checked luggage, at twenty kilograms each, plus one piece of carry-on luggage. I will have to charge you extra for the additional suitcase.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What? Why! I am taking an intercontinental flight! I'm flying sixteen thousand kms! How am I supposed to only take two, twenty kilo bags? That's absurd!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I am sorry, sir, there's nothing I can do. You cannot board the flight with that large bag either. Carry-on bags must fit in the over-head compartment or under your seat. That bag is clearly too big.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Now I see. You charge next to nothing for an international ticket, but when it comes to charging for any other small thing, you charge an arm and a leg! So tell me, miss, how much will I have to pay for all of this.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Let's see... six hundred and twenty-five US dollars.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: That's more than my round-trip ticket!

vocabulary.definition: Very cheap, inexpensive
Get on the plane
Between continents
The bags that one can carry onto the plane
Piece of luggage; one bag
Register bags with the airline and give them to be put on the plane
A document showing the identity of someone when outside his country
Phrase used to indicate that something is very expensive
A device that senses the presence of metal
A pass that authorizes a passenger to get on an airplane
An instrument or machine for weighing
A short stop or break in a journey, usually imposed by scheduling requirements
A trip from one place to another and back, usually over the same route

title: Intermediate - Looking for an Apartment
description: Learn looking for an apartment through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hi! We are the Christianson's! We are here to see the apartment.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh, hi! Sure, come on in! Well, as you can see, the place has just been renovated. The previous tenants left a huge mess here, so the landlord has redone everything.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: It looks great. It's so bright and airy! What great light! I really like these hardwood floors. What's the square footage of this place?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, it's about 120 square meters, or 1300 square feet, more or less. Oh, the landlord has also installed new kitchen appliances. There's a new dishwasher, and a professional-grade gas range. Really, at this price, this place is an amazing deal!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I love it! But what are the payment terms?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: First and last month rent as deposit and rent is due on the 1st of every month. Considering the amount of money invested into the apartment, it's a very good deal!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Yes, it is! Too good to be true...

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: The living room and dinning room are quite spacious as you can see, and down this hall, here's the master bedroom. It has a huge walk-in closet and an en suit bathroom. We can't go in there yet as the police... I mean the clean up crew hasn't finished.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: What do you mean? What's in here?

vocabulary.definition: Please come in
The person that rents a house
Disorder, unorganized
The owner of the apartment
Spacious so that air moves freely
Showing how big one space is measured in feet

Good enough to satisfy professional use
A stove that uses gas to cook
Large; having lots of space

A bathroom within the main bedroom

title: Intermediate - New Guy In Town 5
description: Learn new guy in town 5 through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: What the heck is going on! Did you see that? What was that thing?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I don't know! I'm just glad we made it out! Look, there is a police car! Help! Help! Please stop!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Officer, officer, there is, like, a witch creature back there! We tied her up but she broke free, and she was about to have us for dinner!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: We are telling the truth! She's in there! We suspected her of being a kidnapper or rapist but it turns out she's an alien or something.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ugg! Seriously! Are you gonna help us or not?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Be careful! She might be hiding!

vocabulary.definition: Hell in a more polite form
Able to escape or flee
A living thing
Get out of something
Let me
Regard someone as a criminal or to be guilty

title: Intermediate - Daddy Please
description: Learn daddy please through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hey daddy! You look great today; I like your tie! By the way, I was wondering can I…

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: NO!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I haven’t even told you what it is yet!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Okay, okay, what do you want?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Do you think I could borrow the car? I'm going to a concert tonight.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Um.. I don't think so. I need the car tonight to pick up your mother.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ugg! I told you about it last week! Smelly Toes is playing, and Eric asked if I would go with him!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Who’s this Eric guy?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Duh! He’s like the hottest and most popular guy at school! Come on, dad! Please!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: No can do... sorry.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Fine then! Would you mind giving me 100 bucks?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: No way!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That's so unfair!

vocabulary.definition: Used to change the topic of a conversation
Think about if something is possible
A public performance of music
Go and get
Very well known and well liked
Informal word for dollars
Not fair, not just

title: Intermediate - Carnival in Rio
description: Learn carnival in rio through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I can't believe we're here! Carnival in Rio! Seriously, this is like a once in a lifetime opportunity! Can you believe it? We're here at the biggest party in the world!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I know! We're so lucky that we found tickets for the Sambadrome! Good thing we found that ticket scalper.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Look! It's starting! Wow, this is amazing! Look at how many dancers there are. Oh my gosh! The costumes are so colorful! This is so cool!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: It says here that the school that is dancing now is one of the oldest and most prestigious samba schools in Rio.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: No kidding! Look at them, they're amazing! Look at that girl on the top of that float! She must be the carnival queen! Move over there so I can get a picture of you!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ok. Hurry up take the picture!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh really.... no I can't. No really, I don't know how to dance! Honey I'll see you later!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Patrick! Don't just leave me here!

title: Intermediate - Going To The Dentist
description: Learn going to the dentist through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hey, Gary, great to see you again. Please have a seat. So tell me, what seems to be the problem?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Thanks, doc. I've got a really bad toothache! I can't eat anything, and look, my face is all swollen. I think it might be my wisdom tooth.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, let's have a look. Open wide. Hmm... this doesn't look good. Well, it looks like you have a cavity and your crown is loose. We'll need to put in a filling before it gets any worse, and the crown probably needs to be refitted. I'm going to order some x-rays.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Is it gonna hurt?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: No, not at all! Just lay back and relax.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ok, spit.

vocabulary.definition: Sit down
Tooth pain
Some parts are bigger than others due to a certain disease
Big tooth at the back of your mouth which grows in one's adulthood
Take a glance
A hole in a tooth
The part of the tooth which can be seen
Something that fills the hole of the tooth
A medical examination that takes a picture of your bones
To use a thin thread or string to clean between your teeth
A liquid that is used to clean your mouth and teeth and to make your breath smell better

title: Intermediate - You Are Fired
description: Learn you are fired through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hi Isabel! You wanted to see me?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes Anthony, come on in. Have a seat.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Is everything okay? You seem a bit preoccupied.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, Anthony, this is not going to be an easy conversation. The company has made some decisions which will have a direct impact on your employment.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay...

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I don't want to beat around the bush so I'm just gonna come out with it. We are going to have to let you go.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: What? Why? I mean... just like that? I'm fired?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'm sorry but, to be honest, you are a terrible employee!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: What! I resent that!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Anthony, you were caught making international calls from the office phone, you called in sick in eight times this month and you smell like alcohol!

vocabulary.definition: Worried; thinking about something else
Connected to, related to
Strong influence or effect
Avoid saying something by talking about other things
Say something directly
Have someone fired or dismissed
Used to say something directly
Find something very insulting
Call the office to say you can't come to work because you're sick
Money or benefits you give someone when they are fired

The action of ending employment because of business reasons

title: Intermediate - Groundbreaking Research
description: Learn groundbreaking research through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: We've been over this a thousand times. The data is irrefutable! Look, we've done extensive research, built studies, and read the literature, and there is conclusive evidence to support my theory!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Horowitz, I beg to differ. Even in your most recent study, the investigative approach was flawed! You know as well as I do that the collection of data was not systematic, and there is a large margin of error. To draw a definitive conclusion based on that data would be misleading

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: That is preposterous!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You are trying to single-handedly solve one of the world's greatest mysteries, and yet you are oblivious to the fact that you are wrong!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I am not wrong! The chicken came first!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: No! The egg came first!

vocabulary.definition: A final judgment that is not able to be changed; that is final
Do something on your own, without help
Way of looking for information
Having errors or mistake
Crazy, foolish, or silly
Unaware or don't know
Very full and complete study to find information
Using a careful system or method
Correct; not able to be proved wrong
Linked or connected with
A collection of facts that implies or suggests something to be true, but does not prove it
Show something to be true
An argument that is capable of making people believe that point of view
Find out if something is true

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Wait... what? What do do you mean?

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: B

title: Intermediate - Malfunction
description: Learn malfunction through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hey Carl, can you make a copy of this contract for me please? When you have it ready, send it out ASAP to our subbranch.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure! Um... I think I broke this thing. Maxine, can you help me out here? I'm not really a tech guy.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure! Dammit! Everything in this office seems to be breaking down! Never mind. I'll send this stupid fax later. Oh great! Is someone playing a practical joke on me? This is ridiculous!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I have to go up fifteen floors! Never mind. Made it! There is the copier!

vocabulary.definition: As soon as possible
Technology
Ink used in a printer or photocopier
While moving from one place to another
Suddenly stop working
Forget the last thing I said; don't worry about it

Very unreasonable or silly
A problem causing a thing to stop working properly

Tools used in an office

Break or harm something, make something not work properly, or not look perfect

title: Intermediate - Planning a Bank Robbery
description: Learn planning a bank robbery through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: All right, so this is what we are going to do. I've carefully mapped this out, so don't screw it up. Mr. Rabbit, you and Mr. Fox will go into the bank wearing these uniforms. We managed to get replicas of the one the guards wear when they pick up the money.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Got it.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: When you get inside, tell them that you are filling in for Carl and Tom, and say that they are on another route today. Don't lose your cool. Just act natural.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What if they want to call and confirm?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: You let him.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Don’t worry, we have the phones tapped, so the call will be patched through to me, and I’ll pretend to be the transport company.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ha ha, you are so clever boss!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, shut up. Only take as much money as you can fit in these bags. Don’t get greedy! Are you ready? Let's go.

vocabulary.definition: Mess up, make a mistake, fail

title: Intermediate - Im sorry I love you 5

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'm sorry I haven't called or anything, but right after you decided you wanted a break, I was called up north to put out some major forest fires! I was in the middle of nowhere, working day and night, trying to prevent the blaze from spreading! It was pretty intense.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Oh, honey, I'm glad you're okay! But I have some exciting news... I think I'm pregnant!

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: What's wrong? Why are you asking these questions?

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A

title: Intermediate - Applying for a Visa
description: Learn applying for a visa through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: So, you're applying for a B2 visa, where is your final destination and what's the purpose of your trip to the United States?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'm going to visit my brother; he's just had a baby. He lives in Minneapolis.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: And how long do you you plan to remain in the United States?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'll be here for approximately three weeks. See, here's my return ticket for the twenty-sixth of March.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: And, who is sponsoring your trip?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: My brother, here, this is an invitation letter from him. I will stay with him and his family in their home.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Alright, tell me about the ties you have to your home country.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I own a house; actually, I'm leaving my dog there with my neighbors. I have a car at home, and oh, my job! I'm employed by Tornel as an engineer. Actually, I only have three weeks' vacation, so I have to go back to work at the end of March.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: And what evidence do you have that you are financially independent?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I do have assets in my country; like I said, I own a house, and see, here's a bank statement showing my investments, and my bank balance.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, sir, we cannot grant you a B2 visa at this time, instead, you are granted a resident visa! Congratulations, you are the millionth person to apply for a visa! You win! Congratulations!

title: Intermediate - Buying a Car
description: Learn buying a car through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Hi there, can I help you folks?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'm just browsing; seeing what's on the lot. My daughter wants a car for her birthday, you know how it is.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: She is right, you know. Kids these days all have cars. Let me show you something we just got in: a 1996 sedan. Excellent gas mileage, it has dual airbags and anti lock brakes; a perfect vehicle for a young driver.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I see... What can you tell me about this one?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Oh, that's just an old World War Two tank that we use for TV commercials. Now about this sedan...

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, Sir, if you are looking for quality and safety then look no further! Three inches of reinforced steel protect your daughter from short range missile attacks.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Does the sedan protect her from missile attacks?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: It does not.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I don't know. Let me sleep on it.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Did I mention the tank is a tank?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'll take it!

title: Intermediate - Chinese New Year
description: Learn chinese new year through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I'm so excited about Chinese New Year! When do I get to visit Grandma? Grandma makes the best dumplings in the world!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ha ha, right. Sounds to me like you're more excited about the dumplings than seeing your Grandma.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Of course I miss Grandma, too. I bet she's gonna teach me how to play Mahjong! Hey, Dad, are you going to buy me firecrackers this year? We're going to have the best fireworks! I'm really looking forward to lighting them!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Son, firecrackers aren't toys; they're dangerous!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: No, fireworks are awesome!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Whoa, don't you remember? Last year when I set off the firecrackers, you covered both your ears and hid behind your mother?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Dad! I was scared because... because I saw a bug. That's all.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hahaha... really?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Oh, and I can't wait to watch the dragon dance! Dad, can I sit on your shoulders this time?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hey, I offered last year...

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, I... anyways, I was just thinking of the red envelopes. I wanna make a list of all the things I'm gonna buy with my red envelope money! I can't wait! I'm gonna have so much money! Mom, can I get a pen and a piece of paper?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I want a new transformer, no, two transformers...the Optimus Prime, and...maybe the wheeljack? I'll get a PSP game, hahaha, and I'll buy the entire class lunch at MacDonald's...

title: Intermediate - Hes not a good fit

dialogue.text: So, Lauren, I just wanted to talk to you quickly about our new customer support representative, Jason Huntley.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Sure, what's up?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Basically, I've got a few concerns about him, and the bottom line is, I don't think he's a good fit for our company.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Okay... what makes you say that? I thought you were pleased with his overall performance. Didn't you just tell me last week how impressed you were with his attitude?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Yeah, his attitude is great, but he's really unreliable. Sometimes he's really productive, but then other times... take last Tuesday for instance, he was forty-five minutes late for our morning meeting!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, I'm sure he had a perfectly good reason...

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: But that's not the only thing... you know, he really doesn't have the best work ethic, I'm constantly catching him on MSN and Facebook when he should be talking to clients.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, but come on, Geoff, as if you don't check Facebook at work. Look, you hired this guy, we've invested a lot of time and money in his training, so now it's up to you to coach him. Make it work, Geoff!

title: Intermediate - Opening a Bank Account
description: Learn opening a bank account through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Next, please. May I help you, sir?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Hello, yes, I'd like to open a bank account.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Certainly, I can can help you with that. What type of account would you like to open? A chequing or a savings account?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What What features do they offer?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, if you just take a look here, see, with our chequing account, you can have unlimited daily transactions for a small monthly fee, and our savings account has a higher interest rate, but you must carry a minimum balance of $ 10,000 dollars.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I see, well, I think I'm more interested in a chequing account; I like to have easy access to my money.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Alright, then, with this chequing account you'll be issued a debit card and a cheque book. Will you require overdraft protection? There is an extra fee for that.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: No, that won't be necessary.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: In that case, I'll get you to fill out this paperwork; I'll need your social insurance number, and two pieces of government ID. If you could just sign here, and here, and here; we'll be all set. Would you like to make a deposit today?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yes, I'd like to deposit one billion dollars.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Oh...I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Are you okay?

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: B

title: Intermediate - Cleaning the House

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Honey, the house is such a mess! I need you to help me tidy up a bit. My boss and her husband are coming over for dinner and the house needs to be spotless!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I'm in the middle of something right now. I'll be there in a second.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: This can't wait! I need your help now!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Alright, alright. I'm coming.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Ok, here's a list of chores we need to get done. I'll do the dishes and get all the groceries for tonight. You can sweep and mop the floors. Oh, and the furniture needs to be dusted.

dialogue.speaker: B

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Sure that's fine. Here is the list of all the things you need to get. Don’t forget anything! And can you pick up a bottle of wine on your way home?

dialogue.speaker: A

title: Upper - Intermediate Im Sorry I Love You 8
description: Learn intermediate im sorry i love you 8 through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Veronica! Veronica! Veronica! Are you OK?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Steven! What's going on! Who were those guys? I didn't know you have a gun! What's going on!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I will come clean as soon as we get to safety, OK? For now, you have to trust me, please! I would never do anything to hurt you.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Steven, I...

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Okay, run! I haven't been completely honest with you Veronica, I'm sorry. I'm not a fireman. I'm not even from the United States. I'm a spy for the Indian government.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What? Why didn't you tell me before? What are you doing here?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: When I was a young boy, I used to play cricket my father back in my hometown of Hyderabad. It was a peaceful town, and my father was a renowned chemist. One day, he was approached by members of the CIA, claiming that my father had made the discovery of the millennium in his small lab back at the university where he taught bio-chemistry. I never saw him again. I vowed to discover the whereabouts of my father and consequently joined the Indian Intelligence Bureau.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What does that have to do with those men shooting at us? Most importantly, why did you lie to me!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, I wasn't supposed to meet you. I wasn't supposed to fall in love with you, but you have to believe me when I tell you that what I feel for you is real.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: I can't believe this! Why are all these things happening to me! I can't take it anymore! Let me out of the car!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Veronica, wait!

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Help! Are you a doctor? My poor little Frankie has stopped breathing! Oh my gosh, Help me! I tried to perform CPR, but I just don’t know if I could get any air into his lungs! Oh, Frankie!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ellen, get him hooked up to a monitor! Someone page Dr. Howser. Get the patient to hold still, I can’t get a pulse! Okay, he’s on the monitor. His BP is falling! He's flatlining!

dialogue.speaker: A

dialogue.speaker: B

title: Upper - Intermediate Live from Washington
description: Learn intermediate live from washington through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: This is Madeline Wright, for BCC News reporting live from Washington D. C. where, very shortly, the new President will deliver his inaugural address. Just moments ago, the President was sworn in to office; following the United States Constitution the president swore an oath to faithfully execute the office of the presidency.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: And what exactly is going on now, Madeline?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, Tom, true to American tradition, the band has just played Hail to the Chief, and the President has been honored by a 21 gun salute. Now we're waiting for the President to take to the stage and deliver his speech. Tom, it's like a who's who of the political world here on Capital Hill, with dignitaries representing several different countries.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: What's the mood on the ground like, Madeline?

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: In a word, the mood here is electric. The excitement in the air is palpable; I've never seen a larger crowd here on Capital Hill, and the audience is shouting crying, and embracing each other. On this, a most historic day, you can feel the hope and the excitement in the air. The twentieth of January will go down in history as the... Oh, Tom, it looks like the President is about to to begin...

title: Upper - Intermediate Planning for the Worst
description: Learn intermediate planning for the worst through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, right, let’s move to our next order of business, as many of you are aware, in recent weeks there has been a lot of media coverage surrounding this bird flu issue. And it's come to my attention that our company lacks any sort of bird flu c

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Basically, we need to come up with a clear plan; we need to outline specific actions that our company can take to maintain critical business functions in case a pandemic strikes.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: So, what I’d like to do is: first appoint someone to look after drafting our plan; Ralph, I’d like you to head up this project.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, let’s see, there are a few points we need to be thinking about... first, I’ll need you to analyze our numbers and figure out what kind of financial impact an outbreak might have.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: You’ll also need to think about how we can avoid any of our employees getting infected; think of ways to reduce employee-customer contact, perhaps some IT solutions that will allow our people to work from home.

dialogue.speaker: A

title: Upper - Intermediate New Guy in Town
description: Learn intermediate new guy in town through this lesson.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Oh, I don't know if you heard, but someone moved into that old house down the road.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Yeah, I know. I met the owner of the house yesterday as he was moving in. His name is Armand.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Really? What's he like? You have to fill me in.

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Actually, he's a bit strange. I don't know... I've got a bad feeling about him.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Really? Why?

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Well, yesterday I brought over a housewarming gift, but Armand started acting really weird, and then he practically kicked me out! I tried to, sort of, peek into his house, but everything was so dark inside that I couldn't really get a good look.

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: Well, you'll never guess what I saw this morning. A delivery truck pulled into his driveway, and it dropped off a long, rectangular box. It almost looked like a coffin!

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: You see! Why would he...

dialogue.speaker: B
dialogue.text: Ah, Armand! You scared the heck out of me! This is my friend Doris.

Tell me about it

Strange, unusual

vocabulary.definition: Cause someone to feel a lot of fear
